journal-meta.journal-title: Asia Pacific Journal of Management Research and Innovation

title-group.article-title: Does the Dividend Announcement Matter in the Indian Stock Market?

contrib.aff: Santosh Kumar, Assistant Professor, Faculty of Management Studies, Amity University, Noida. E-mail: santosh.frm@gmail.com
Raju G., Head, Department of Commerce, Government College, Nedumangad, Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala. E-mail: drrajug@yahoo.co.in

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2013 Asia-Pacific Institute of Management SAGE Publications

abstract.p: Over the past few years, many firms have announced dividends which give conclusive but indirect signal to the investors. The Dividend is declared to show sufficient profitability to finance future expansion in the firms. Dividend declarations have become an important area in financial research considering its strong implications for corporate policy. The article investigates the signalling effect of the dividend announcements and also the significance of cumulative abnormal return of dividend announcements before and after the event day. Further it also tests the evidence of average abnormal return around the announcement date. The analysis uses data of 42 firms in the BSE 500 index, which have announced dividends during the period 2007–2009. An examination of share price behaviour around dividend announcements proves the signalling effect of these announcements. These results strongly support that the share prices drift positively in the case of dividend announcements and the market particularly reacts more favourably to dividend announcements.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The stock market has been found to react to various corporate announcements. Few such significant announcements, which have bearing on the stock price movement of the firm, are earnings and dividend information disclosure. This phenomenon is reflected in the abnormal stock return of the company surrounding the announcement. The magnitude of abnormal return provides a direct measure of unexpected change in security holders’ wealth associated with the event. However, the magnitude of the effect and the time taken to incorporate the information content of dividend announcements vary from market to market and depend on characteristics of the firm under study. If dividend announcements have informational significance for investor, then such announcement should induce abnormal stock return during the period surrounding the announcement. Thus the information disclosure and its likely impact form the basis to measure the efficiency of market.

sec.title: Review of Literature
sec.p: Mallikarjunappa and Manjunatha (2009) examine the stock price reactions to dividends and find that average abnormal returns for 30 days do not approximate to zero and cumulative average abnormal return show the wide fluctuations indicating that abnormal returns can be earned several days after the event day and thus Indian stock market is not efficient in semi strong form. Kosedag and Jinhu (2009) find that the dividend yield has no additional power beyond the standardised dividend change in explaining the announcement period excess returns. Results are consistent with the information or signalling hypothesis, but inconsistent with the dividend clientele hypothesis. Arab (2004) is of the opinion that the dividend policy behaviour of corporations operating in emerging markets is significantly different from the widely accepted dividend policy behaviour of corporations operating in developed market. Chander et al. (2007) observes the incidences of average abnormal returns for CAPM around the dividend announcement indicating over expectation of investors regarding dividend announcement in the information leakage phase, which has subsided considerably with new information disclosure. On the other hand the dividend announcement does not inspire much over to the over enthusiastic investors in rising capital markets.

Saleh (2007) is of the opinion that investors achieve positive abnormal returns in the pre-announcement period. Thus few investors have access to information prior to becoming public. In Australian stock market, Balachandran (2004) finds strong support for the information content/ signalling hypothesis for special dividend announcement that do not participate in Dividend Reinvestment Plans (DRP) and limited support for those associated with DRP. Moreover dividend announcement is equally important for those markets where the corporate ownership structure is notably different from the developed market. Asamoah (2010) observes the Ghana stock exchange and finds that GSE is not semi-strong efficient and concludes that GSE must address itself to three forms of efficiency-operational efficiency, allocation efficiency and pricing efficiency. Gurgul and Majdosz (2005) also argues that the dividend has positive impact on the share price.

Capstaff et al. (2004) examine the reaction of stock price to dividend announcement in Oslo Stock Exchange. He finds that the stock market reaction is most pronounced for large, positive dividend announcements that are followed by permanent cash flow increases. This lends moderate support for the signalling theory of dividends in Norway. Batchelor and Orakcioglu (2003) investigate the proposition that stock dividends have no effect on company value, using a novel GARCH process with event related intercept terms to capture induced changes in the volatility of stock prices. Return rise in advance of stock dividends payments, but this effect becomes statistically insignificant when proper allowance is made for heteroscedasticity. Volatility rises after stock dividend payments and this is attributed to persistence following exceptionally large price movements around the ex-dividend day, rather than to any transitory rise in the unconditional returns variance.

The various studies conducted worldwide on stock market reaction to public announcements shows that market’s reaction to such publicly available information is very swift. Inefficiency in the market exists when investors envisage such information before it is formally announced and earn abnormal returns. Therefore, a comprehensive study is conducted to investigate the impact of dividend announcements on share prices.

sec.title: Objective and Hypothesis
sec.p: The objective of our study is to analyze whether the market recognizes any differences between stock return before and after the event day if dividends are announced and further also to explore the correlation between the return before and after the event day. This leads to the following hypothesis:
H0: Dividend announcement have no significant impact on stock price movement in the Indian stock Market.
H1: Dividend announcement have significant impact on stock price movement in the Indian stock Market.

sec.title: Dividend Announcement
sec.p: The sample consists of dividend announcements obtained from the online database of Bombay Stock Exchange between January 2007 and December 2009. (Although related several announcements are recorded in the review period, the scope of this article is limited to dividend announcement only.)

caption.p: List of Companies with Dividend Announcements

table-wrap-foot.p: Source: Collected and compiled by the authors (using raw data from Bombay Stock Exchange).

sec.p: The stock prices and the values of index are obtained from BSE database. The details of companies which declared dividends are taken from the website of Money Control. In addition, the data is free of day-of-the-week skew as the announcements are evenly spread across all four trading days.

The study of the announcements effect has been made by using the 42 dividend announcements of 42 companies in the BSE 500 index, which have announced dividends during the period 2007–2009. ‘Event study’ methodology using daily returns along with the market model are used for the purpose of analyzing the dividend announcements effect. This method was originally introduced by Ball and Brown (1968) and subsequently modified by MacKinlay (1997) to determine abnormal return and average abnormal return and cumulative average abnormal return (hereafter will be referred as MacKinlay model (1997). The dates on which announcements are released are defined as the event dates (t = 0), provided the stocks have been traded on that date. In the eventuality of announcement during non-trading days, the trading day immediately following the announcement has been assigned as event date. This has been done in order to investigate the announcement effect immediately after the announcement. The effects of announcements on equity share prices have been examined by taking daily-adjusted market price data. The 8 days surrounding the announcement of dividends (i.e., t = –4 to t = +4) is assigned as the ‘event period’. For each announcement, the 4-trading day prior to the event window is used to determine the parameters for the market model, technically known as ‘estimation window’ (t = –4 to t = +4).

sec.title: Short-term Abnormal Returns
sec.p: The first step in the analysis of the impact of actual stock repurchase on the level of abnormal returns requires computing the market adjusted Cumulative Abnormal Returns (CAR) for the sample of total 42 firms over a five-day trading period starting on the announcement date. By examining this shorter interval, the analysis investigates whether the abnormal returns just after the announcement ultimately impact the subsequent levels of repurchases. (The announcement date is included since the publication date will be normally a trading date and investors have the opportunity to respond to such announcements on the same date.) Standard event-study procedures are used to calculate the abnormal returns. The abnormal return in any given period is the market model residual, which is the difference between the stock’s actual return and the predicted return based on the market return for that period. Hence the market adjusted abnormal returns are calculated as:(1)ARij = RTij-RM
Where ARij is the abnormal return for firm j on day i.
RTij is the actual return for firm j on day i.
The total percentage return to shareholders (RTt ) on day t is given by the expression:(RTt ) = [(Pt – Pt –1) (100)]/(Pt –1)
And RMi is the return on the BSE 500 Index on day i.
The market adjusted abnormal returns are calculated as in Equation (1) above. The five-day cumulative abnormal returns for each firm are calculated as:5-Day CARij = ∑ARij, for days i = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4
Where, the announcement day is day 0.

Cumulative abnormal returns (CARj) are then averaged over the five-day period starting on the announcement date to obtain the five-day cumulative average abnormal returns (CAAR) as:5-Day AAR = (∑CARj)/n for all firms j = 1, 2,… n

The average abnormal returns (AAR) are then compared for statistical difference between the means at different days in estimation window. Statistical significance in the difference in the means would indicate that abnormal return is related to the level of repurchases undertaken during the estimation window.

The next step is to compute the daily cross sectional average abnormal returns (AAR), for a specific day. It is computed by summing the daily abnormal returns for each observation across companies and dividing this figure with the total observations on that day. This is done for the whole estimation window.
In order to find out the impact the announcements have on the stocks, we calculate the average of the Abnormal Returns (AAR) using the period of –4, +4, which implies that particular change.

Where ARit is the abnormal return for the ith firm on day t and n is the length of the estimation period. According to the theory, when abnormal performance is spread in a period, that is, not clustered, the best way to calculate AAR is CAR. Cumulative Abnormal Return (CAR) is the sum of AARt of the firms during the estimation period –4, +4.

The t statistic of the CAR is used to test the hypothesis whether the AAR on the exact day of the announcement and the CAR during the estimation period are both zero. Since the event dates spread into periods, we can assume cross sectional independence of the data. Further we also use paired t test to observe the effect of announcement before and after the announcement. The mean of different days CAR is also tested with ANOVA. Although this study provides significant insight into the effectiveness of dividend announcement, it is not without its limitations. Abnormal returns in stocks are due to concerned announcements (dividend) and assuming other factors as constant and they do not influence share prices. This study concerns only a particular period and hence business cycle influence is not adjusted according to the exposure of the company, but according to the market movement.

sec.title: Impact of Dividend on the Stock Price and Return
sec.p: Table 3 presents the descriptive statistics of 5-day (including the day of announcement) CAR before and after the dividend announcements. Further Tables 4 and 5 depict the correlation between the two and the paired t test statistics, respectively. It is evident from the descriptive statistics that 5-day CAR before the announcement is –3.02 where as the 5-day CAR after the announcement is –0.58. The sharp difference in CAR before and after the announcement is attributed to strong signalling of share price behaviour in Indian stock market. Thus, the investors act positively in the case of dividend announcement. The paired t test sample statistics between pre CAR and post CAR is very high (0.54) and significant (Table 4) reflecting the importance of dividend announcement in the fluctuation of stock price and return. The results of paired t test (Table 5) also confirm that the stock returns are significantly different before and after the announcements. Thus, we reject the null hypothesis (H0) that there is no significant impact of dividend announcement on the stock return. Table 6 depicts the CAR and AAR surrounding dividend announcements in different periods centred on the announcement day (announcement day = 0). We find majority of the CAR and AAR at different days (1 to 4) are insignificant independently, attributing to unknown sentiment driven fluctuations in the stock market but the direction of movements in the price is almost positive after the announcement. We further observe that CAR at different days is also insignificant (Table 6: ANOVA Results) leaving negligible scope for arbitrage. It further indicates that the information is quickly absorbed by the stock price probably due to larger firm size in our samples.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this study, it is established that the share prices drift positively in the case of dividend announcements. This drift may be attributed to the inclusion of large samples in the study. Large firms are subjected to greater attention by the market participants and therefore, fundamental information is quickly incorporated in prices, leaving no scope for earning superior returns. The study indicates that the dividend announcements primarily serve as a signalling mechanism of management’s view leading to immediate upward swing in the share price movement. But this positive signalling existed only for a day after the announcements, after which the extent of positivism of shares is almost insignificant. Results are also in consistent with the observations of Chander (2007) who is of the opinion that in rising capital market, dividend announcements do not inspire much to the investors. Further it may be due to faster absorption of information in larger firms. Thus the correction of price happens in a very short span of time leading to semi strong efficiency.

ref.citation: Arab Mounira Ben Sedrine Ben Nadia Adel Karaa (2004). Shareholders reaction to dividend announcement in an emerging market: Evidence from Tunisian stock exchange. Finance India, 18(3), 1295–1314.
Asamoah Gordon Newlove (2010). The impact of dividend announcement on share price behavior in Ghana. Journal of Business & Economics Research, 8(4), 47–58.
Ball Ray Phillip Brown (1968). An empirical evaluation of accounting income numbers. Journal of Accounting Research, 6(2), 159–178.
Batchelor Roy Ismail Orakcioglu (2003). Event-related GARCH: The impact of stock dividends in Turkey. Applied Financial Economics, 13(4), pp. 295–337.
Balachandran Balasingham Nguyen Tuan Anh (2004). Signaling power of special dividends in an imputation environment. Accounting & Finance, 44(3), 277–297.

Capstaff John Audun Klæboe Marshall Andrew P. (2004). Share price reaction to dividend announcements: Empirical evidence on the signaling model from the Oslo Stock Exchange. Multinational Finance Journal, 8(1/2), 115–139.
Chander Ramesh Renuka Sharma Kiran Mehta (2007). Dividend announcement and informational efficiency: An empirical study of Indian stock market. ICFAI Journal of Applied Finance, 13(10), 29–42.
Gurgul Henryk Majdosz Paweł (2005). Effect of dividends and repurchase announcements on the Polish market. Operations Research & Decisions, 1(1), 25–41.
Kosedag Arman Qian Jinhu (2009). Do dividend clienteles explain price reactions to dividends changes? International Journal of Business & Finance Research (IJBFR), 3(1), 47–57.
Mackinlay A. Craig (1997). Event studies in economics and finance. Journal of Economic Literature, 35, 13–39.
Mallikarjunappa T. Manjunatha T. (2009). The stock price reaction to dividend announcements. Journal of Management & Public Policy, 1(1), 43–56.
Saleh Walid (2007). Investors reactions to dividend announcements: parametric vs. nonparametric approach. Applied Financial Economics Letters, 3(3), 169–179.
